title-group.article-title: Mirror, mirror on my boss’s wall: Engaged enactment’s moderating role on the relationship between perceived narcissistic supervision and work outcomes

abstract.p: Addressing both practical and scholarly considerations, we investigated the interactive effects of perceived supervisor narcissism and individual enactment behavior on four relevant self-report work outcomes (i.e. frustration, tension, resource availability, and job performance). We hypothesized that employees with limited enactment behavior would be adversely affected in high supervisor narcissism settings. Conversely, we expected that perceived narcissistic supervision would have little effect on those with active enactment strategies. Across three samples, hypotheses were strongly supported as work frustration (Studies 1 and 3) and tension increased (Studies 1 and 2), and resource availability (Studies 1–3) and job performance (Studies 1–3) decreased for low enactment behavior–high perceived supervisor narcissism employees. Conversely, perceived supervisor narcissism had no significant effect for high enactment employees on any outcome across samples. These findings, when viewed in their entirety, confirmed the influential role of enactment behavior on perceived supervisor narcissism–work outcome relationships.

disp-quote.p: ‘The human does not react to an environment, he creates it.’ (Weick, 1969: 64)

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Recent research has confirmed the pervasiveness of malevolent leadership behavior (Shao et al., 2011) marked by increases in workplace hostility (Trzesniewski et al., 2008), counterproductive work behavior (Tepper et al., 2011), corporate scandals (Lerner and Tetlock, 1999), and lapses in decision-making (Paul et al., 2002). Abusive leadership ‘degrades the quality of life for everyone associated with it’ (Hogan and Kaiser, 2005: 169). However, these effects are felt strongest by subordinates who feel victimized, stifled, and asked to do more than others often with little reciprocal credit. As a consequence, liking and trust are eroded largely owing to subordinates’ deteriorating views of leader competency, objectivity, and support (Harvey et al., 2006).

In explaining this phenomenon, scholars have linked supervisors’ dysfunctional behavior with self-serving motives (Tepper et al., 2012), especially those viewed as fundamentally narcissistic. Differentiating these variables, Hogan and Hogan’s (2001) taxonomy described narcissism as a common antecedent of abusive leadership rather than a term to be used synonymously (Padilla et al., 2007). Additionally, scholars recognize that leader narcissism predicts employee abuse more robustly when coupled with supportive contextual factors (Galvin et al., 2010).

The inherent lack of empathy, exaggerated sense of importance, and purposeful exploitation of others associated with the supervisor narcissism construct (Campbell et al., 2011) introduces a level of tension not experienced in settings with characteristically less egocentric leader behavior. At extreme levels, supervisor’s self-serving behavior can adversely influence subordinates’ physical and psychological well-being (Padilla et al., 2007). However, individual difference studies confirm a lack of uniformity with respect to consequences (i.e. Humphreys et al., 2010). Extending this discussion, we contend that coping in the form of purposive environment creation (Maitlis and Sonenshein, 2010) will affect how perceived supervisor narcissism influences subordinate perceptions of work attitudes and behaviors. Frustration, tension, resource availability, and performance represent self-report outcomes in this research given their prior corroborated associations with self-serving leader behaviors (Hershcovis and Barling, 2010).

sec.title: Theoretical foundations and hypothesis development
sec.p: Often associated with malevolent descriptors such as tyrannical (Ashforth, 1997), toxic (Padilla et al., 2007), pseudo-transformational (Dasborough and Ashkanasy, 2002), and undermining (Duffy et al., 2006), abusive leadership represents ‘subordinates’ perceptions of the extent to which their supervisors engage in the sustained display of hostile verbal and non-verbal behaviors, excluding physical contact’ (Tepper, 2000: 178). In terms of underlying motives, abusive supervisors exploit power, principally, for personal gain and power accrual (Ashforth, 1997). From the subordinate’s perspective, leader mistreatment is considered intentional, self-serving, and stress-provoking (Tepper, 2007).

In support, recent studies have corroborated relationships between supervisor abuse and a variety of maladaptive employee reactions in both work (Tepper et al., 2001) and non-work settings. As documented, consequences of leader mistreatment include psychological stress and job dissatisfaction (Tepper, 2000), job burnout (Fox and Stallworth, 2010), turnover intent (Tepper et al., 2009), and feelings of hopelessness/humiliation (Starrat and Grandy, 2010). Further, recent meta-analytic studies (Hershcovis and Barling, 2010) report relationships between supervisor aggression and commitment, exhaustion, depression, and deviant activity (interpersonal and organizational). In terms of non-work consequences, Hoobler and Brass (2006) found that abusive supervision influenced subordinate treatment of family members while away from work.

Recently, scholars have called for a more refined treatment of maladaptive leader behavior (Hershcovis et al., 2007), including greater consideration of the ‘why’ of targeted mistreatment (Tepper et al., 2011). To address this substantive recommendation, and hence expand the existing research base, we focus on perceived narcissistic supervision.

sec.title: Societal narcissism
sec.p: In both theory and practice, the origins of narcissistic behavior are often traced to Ovid’s Metamorphoses (Pincus and Lukowitsky, 2010). In this poem, a handsome young man named Narcissus rejects the overtures of an admiring nymph named Echo, instead falling in love with a reflecting pool’s image of himself from which he is unable to detach. The pain associated with unrequited love lead each to experience loneliness and avoidable death – Narcissus starving while staring at his own likeness and Echo eventually turning to stone.

Despite a reputed clinical history in psychoanalytic realms (Kernberg, 1975), only recently have investigations focused on the etiology of narcissism in organizational settings (Judge et al., 2006). Principally, contemporary narcissism research has relied on the American Psychiatric Association’s (Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, DSM-IV, 2000) definition for theory development as well as measurement. As conceptualized, narcissism includes an exaggerated sense of self-importance, preoccupations with limitless success, a perceived specialness/entitlement, an admiration-seeking focus, and an indifference towards others (Brown et al., 2009). Predictably, research documents relationships between elevated narcissism levels and heightened emotionality (Emmons, 1984), a lack of remorse (Exline et al., 2004), and egocentric attributions for success and failure (Morf and Rhodewalt, 2001). Also, excessive narcissism triggers self-regulatory behaviors designed to establish superiority (Bushman and Baumeister, 1998) often at the expense of healthy social relations. In terms of variability, the narcissistic trait is considered stable, but also malleable to contextually-driven cues (Campbell et al., 2002).

sec.title: Narcissistic supervision
sec.p: Complicating (or possibly enhancement of) development is the documented ‘mixed blessing’ associated with narcissism (Brunnell et al., 2008; Paulhus, 1998). Specifically, narcissism is often initially associated with adaptive attributes including sociability (Campbell et al., 2002) and confidence (Emmons, 1984). Also, narcissists are often perceived as creative and resourceful leaders, exhibiting self-sufficiency and charm (Rosenthal and Pittinsky, 2006). Scholars confirm that verbal and nonverbal behavior, physical appearance, and expressions of entitlement are considered attractive by others during initial encounters (Back et al., 2010).

Moreover, Maccoby (2000) argued that narcissistic leaders are perceived as visionaries possessing the skills (e.g. boldness, risk-taking, and charisma) (Rosenthal and Pittinsky, 2006) needed to breed followership, especially in settings considered ambiguous (Maccoby, 2004). Chatterjee and Hambrick (2007) suggested that narcissists are commonly selected as leaders because of their inclination to pursue valiant actions that deviate from the status quo. Finally, scholars have described both ‘constructive’ (Kets de Vries, 1989) and ‘productive’ (Maccoby, 2003) narcissists as leaders capable of influencing others through vision and personal appeal (Humphreys et al., 2010). Despite these favorable attributes (Higgs, 2009), academic and practical attention has focused largely on the destructive effects of narcissistic leaders (Ouimet, 2010), as is our focal interest in this research.

sec.title: Negative supervisor narcissism
sec.p: Narcissistic supervisors cause relationships to deteriorate because their behavior is ‘principally motivated by their own egomaniacal needs and beliefs, superseding the needs and interests of the constituents and institutions they lead’ (Rosenthal and Pittinsky, 2006: 631). Further contributing to this decline, narcissists react to external ego-threat with aggression (Jones and Paulhus, 2010) and other counterproductive work behaviors purposefully harmful to others (Penney and Spector, 2002). In terms of specific anxiety-inducing behaviors, narcissistic leaders’ need for valuation triggers self-promotion tactics (Hogan et al., 1990) that are often ‘deceptive, hostile, and intimidating’ (Glad, 2002: 1).

For subordinates, expressions of supervisors’ image promotion activities vary widely in terms of tactics and intensity (Hochwarter et al., 2007a). In support of directed maltreatment, Campbell and Campbell (2009) argued that narcissistic self-enhancement can occur only through the assistance of others who represent both recipients of abuse and sources of ego-confirming information. Further, Penney and Spector (2002) argued that superiority-fostering motives lead narcissistic leaders to punish those who represent a potential threat or interject negative feedback (i.e. questioning supervisor’s instructions, communicating failures/shortcomings). Moreover, the focus on agentic goals (respect, status, admiration) causes narcissistic leaders to largely disregard subordinate needs (Zeigler-Hill et al., 2010), instead assuming responsibility and credit for others’ positive contributions (Robins and Paulhus, 2001). In these situations, subordinates are often coerced to support the supervisor’s ego-centric beliefs through feigned praise and self-criticism (Kaiser et al., 2008).

Accordingly, supervisor expectations for unmitigated backing create an inequitable exchange climate laden with hostility (Hogan and Roberts, 2000). By definition, the self-importance (Emmons, 1987), inflated self-view (Campbell, Bonacci et al., 2004; Campbell, Goodie et al., 2004), lack of consideration (Brown and Bosson, 2001), and unpredictable mood swings associated with narcissistic leadership (Rhodewalt and Morf, 1998) weakens social exchange ties (El Akremi et al., 2010). Further damaging this relationship is failure to involve subordinates in decision-making (Blair et al., 2008) and reluctance to accept responsibility if self-serving outcomes are less than optimal (Rosenthal and Pittinsky, 2006).

When examined in its entirety, substantive research confirms consistent relationships between narcissistic supervision and a myriad of negative work outcomes. Accordingly, developing studies to better understand potential attenuating factors has both scholarly and applied merit. In practice, narcissistic managers often drive away a firm’s best employees, leaving behind workers who often lack the necessary skills to contribute (Bergman et al., 2010). As a remedy, identifying individual difference factors that mitigate threat reactions could help firms restore lost productivity, repair declining morale, and minimize turnover (Caldwell and Canuto-Carranco, 2010). Finally, an appreciation of motivated reactive strategies will assist employees unable to garner support via organizationally-sanctioned means (Hoel et al., 2010).

sec.title: Responses to narcissistic supervision
sec.p: Scholars confirm a number of potential subordinate reactions to narcissistic supervision (Campbell et al., 2011). If consistent with the tenets of exchange theory (Gouldner, 1960), subordinates would respond to narcissistic behavior with conduct that matches or exceeds supervisor mistreatment (Bies and Tripp, 2001). However, power dependence theory (Emerson, 1962), which describes the role of influence inequities in exchange relationships, suggests that abuse targets are often unable to retaliate negatively owing to resource vulnerability or a fear of counter reprisals (Molm, 1988).

Recognizing the impracticality of antagonistic responses, Tepper et al. (2009) outlined less caustic reactions including reconciliation (attempts to restore the relationship), forgiveness (reducing or eliminating anger toward the perpetrator), and avoidance (distancing oneself from the supervisor). Similarly, Lubit (2002) argued that subordinates of narcissistic leaders will experience less tension if a deferential, complimentary strategy is adopted. Building on this discussion, we contend that a subordinate’s overarching goal when faced with a narcissistic supervisor is to establish a level of personal control that minimizes present and future resource loss (Zellars et al., 2002). As conceptualized, personal environment enactment represents a less contentious approach documented to promote well-being and resource maintenance in threat-laden settings (Maitlis and Sonenshein, 2010).

sec.title: Environment enactment
sec.p: Weick (1995) describes enactment as the proactive processes developed to create, restructure, and (or) abolish features of one’s occupied environment. Comparable discussions underscore the importance of self-formation (Deetz, 1982), social construction (Weick, 1988), and creative problem solving (Heath, 1994) as defining elements. Nicholson (1995) discussed enactment as individuals’ purposeful and active adjustment to settings regarded as inadequate for healthy and successful participation. In terms of a volitional component, Weick (2003: 186) argued that enactment ‘changes the actor from inactive to active and in doing so, deepens the actor’s stake in what is being done and its outcomes.’

In addition, enactment’s response to external vulnerability is consistent with the transactional theory of stress, which argues that anxiety results from an unfavorable imbalance between threat appraisal and resource availability (Lazarus and Cohen, 1977). In terms of an initial evaluation, pressure introduced by perceived intimidation (Ouimet, 2010) promotes the deterioration of well-being if adjustments are delayed or absent (Restubog et al., 2011). In terms of possible corrections, the theory argues that disadvantageous threat-resource ratios trigger either emotional-focused or problem-solving coping (Lazarus and Folkman, 1984). Emotion-focused tactics, which include wishful thinking and seeking emotional guidance, focus on regulating negative emotions (Folkman and Lazarus, 1988). Conversely, problem-solving coping is associated with purposeful actions developed to reduce or eliminate the source of stress (Baker and Berenbaum, 2007). Because it redefines threat, exposes less important components as irrelevant, and focuses on the accumulation of uncertainty-reducing information (Weick, 1988), enactment behavior represents a problem-solving approach within the transactional model.

With respect to potential or actual threat (Carver and Connor-Smith, 2010), enactment shares properties with self-directed behavior, defined as ‘taking initiative in improving current circumstances or creating new ones’ (Crant, 2000: 436). Accordingly, substantial research has focused on enactment’s crisis-environment modifications, arguing that threat-generated interruptions catalyze behavior dedicated to repair and renewal (Maitlis and Sonenshein, 2010). Weick (1988) argues that enactment provides structure, promotes a richer understanding of contextual realities, and encourages the development of situation-appropriate alternatives.

sec.title: Environment enactment as a reaction to narcissistic supervision
sec.p: By definition, enactment influences unpredictable and potentially harmful situations by promoting uncertainty reduction (Daft and Weick, 1984). Weick (1995) contended that heightened ambiguity, often associated with self-serving leader behavior, triggers the search for explanation and potential remedy. Moreover, Parzefall and Coyle-Sharpiro (2011) reported that supervisor breach prompts victims to ‘make sense out of their environment through action’ (p. 14). Weick (2003) concluded that effective enactment normalizes breached environments often by restoring employee expectations to pre-violation levels. Within the context of narcissistic supervision, subordinates enact an environment as a reaction to a dysfunctional form of leadership (Rosenthal and Pittinsky, 2006) that has breach as a defining principle (Campbell et al., 2011).

Furthermore, individuals experience adverse consequences (disappointment, strain, other-serving behavior; Ellis and Shpielberg, 2003) in threat settings where no proactive attempts at remedy are undertaken (Rudolph et al., 2009). Campbell and Campbell (2009) argued that inactivity impedes uncertainty reduction when coupled with volatile or destructive supervisor behavior. In support, Zellars et al. (2002) found that decreased performance motivation and heightened strain resulted when threat perceptions were coupled with insufficient proactive coping. As a plausible explanation for heightened vulnerability, low environment enactment inhibits subordinates from establishing protective boundaries and exploiting previously unforeseen opportunities needed to cope (Hogan and Hogan, 2001).

In contrast, high enactment subordinates are able to improve psychological well-being by influencing interpretations of work environments and channeling subsequent behavior toward preferred outcomes (Smircich and Stubbart, 1985). In this regard, attention associated with enactment promotes controllability by reducing ambiguity and increasing the efficiency of resource use (Orton and Weick, 1990). Similarly, focused enactment behavior imposes limits on the experienced harm generated by threatening social cues by emphasizing protection and self-regulation (Weick, 1996). In terms of developing productive strategies to reduce strain, Weick (1988) argued that enactment produces better understanding of coping and development opportunities than evident before the onset of threat.

Based on this discussion, we expect that high levels of enactment behavior will mitigate the effects of narcissistic supervision on subordinate perceived frustration, tension, resource availability, and performance. Conversely, we predict that the negative attitudes and behaviors of individuals associated with narcissistic supervision will be exacerbated when subordinates are unable to enact protective environments. Each perceived outcome is discussed below.

sec.title: Frustration
sec.p: Defined as an ego-defensive response to interruptions in goal attainment (Rosenzweig, 1944), frustration has been identified as an outcome of threatening social cues including perceived politics (Rosen et al., 2009), injustice (Lillis et al., 2007), and coworker counterproductive work behaviors (Fox and Spector, 1999). Supervisor ego-nurturing behavior, when persistent and focused, provokes frustration because it introduces bias that affects subsequent interactions and reward decisions (Emmons, 1984). Moreover, frustration increases owing to supervisors withholding or eliminating employee development opportunities if viewed as impediments to self-affirmation (Aasland et al., 2010).

Research suggests that narcissistic supervisors’ promotion of counterproductive work behavior is more frustrating for low enactment employees when compared with those actively engaged in environment creation and maintenance (Penney and Spector, 2002). By failing to create an insulative work setting (Daft and Weick, 1984), employees are unable to avert external vulnerabilities that jeopardize goal attainment and well-being (Kets de Vries and Miller, 1985). If unable to generate at least moderate levels of resistance, employees assume the role of passive target for narcissistic supervisors’ often aggressive, unsympathetic, and isolating behavior (Morris et al., 2005). Outwardly, submissive reactions signal target acceptance (Tepper, 2007), or at least a lack of explicit defiance. Given a lack of opposition, a perpetrator’s use of malevolent strategies likely intensifies until optimal self-interested outcomes are achieved.

Conversely, those who proactively pursue enactment build resilience to ward off the consequences of other’s egocentric behavior (Weick and Sutcliffe, 2001), and thus, will experience less frustration. Ambiguity reduction through meaning creation allows once inaccessible frustration-buffering opportunities to surface (Harrison et al., 2011). In further support, favorable interpretations, preparation and prevention (Sonenshein and Dholakia, in press; Weick, 1993) associated with proactive crisis management (Mitroff et al., 1987) contribute to the development of behaviors aimed at minimizing frustration. Based on this discussion, we offer the following hypothesis:

disp-quote.p: Hypothesis 1: Enactment behavior will moderate the relationship between narcissistic behavior and job frustration. Specifically, narcissistic supervision will be associated with increased job frustration when enactment behavior is low. Conversely, high levels of enactment behavior will likely neutralize the effects of narcissistic supervision on job frustration (signifying no effect).

sec.title: Job tension
sec.p: By definition, job tension results when disturbances in the work environment trigger demands that tax or overwhelm adaptive capabilities (Lazarus and Folkman, 1984). Across settings, leader egocentric behavior (i.e. belittling, inappropriate self-enhancement; Campbell and Foster, 2007) has been shown to amplify subordinate anxiety and contribute to declining health (Wink, 1991). Much of this tension is attributable to the leader’s unremitting pursuit of self-validation (Tangney, 2000) coupled with the need to dominate others in ways that operate outside of acceptable social boundaries. As a result, narcissistic supervisor’s targeted manipulation, social isolation, and degradation (Brown and Zeigler-Hill, 2004) creates an incubator for workplace anxiety to flourish (Campbell et al., 2011).

Extending this research, it is expected that the relationship between narcissistic supervision and job tension will be more pronounced for low enactment subordinates. As described, these employees simply do not have the social or structural means to protect themselves when exposed to supervisor’s aversive, status-boosting behavior (Tepper, 2007). Conversely, the protective barrier associated with volitional self- and environmental-adaptation (Aspinwall et al., 2002) will help minimize the strain associated with narcissistic supervisor behaviors. Based on this discussion, we offer the following hypothesis:

disp-quote.p: Hypothesis 2: Enactment behavior will moderate the relationship between narcissistic behavior and job tension. Specifically, narcissistic supervision will be associated with increased job tension when enactment behavior is low. Conversely, high levels of enactment behavior will likely neutralize the effects of narcissistic supervision on job tension (signifying no effect).

sec.title: Resource availability
sec.p: Researchers have defined resources as ‘energy reservoirs at work that individuals can tap to regulate their job demands’ (Van den Tooren and De Jonge, 2010: 40). Categorized as physical or personal characteristics, psychosocial factors, conditions or objects, studies confirm that threat from external agents predicts resource deficiency, deterioration, or unanticipated depletion (Hobfoll, 1989). In terms of employee reactions, inadequate resource availability has been associated with work-induced guilt, low job and life satisfaction (Hochwarter et al., 2007b), heightened politics perceptions (Hochwarter et al., 2010), and accelerated burnout (Hobfoll and Freedy, 1993) in past research.

The self-serving bias common to narcissists inhibits leaders from fostering an environment where resources are easily obtained and shared willingly (Einarsen et al., 2007). Accordingly, studies establish that resource scarcity weakens perceptions of control and hinders coping success when coupled with external threat (Hochwarter et al., 2008). Vredenburgh and Shea-Van Fossen (2010) maintained that narcissists would hoard and defend resources in political settings more vigorously compared with less egocentric leaders. In particular, ‘[u]sing power to better one’s own lot means that followers may then go wanting for the critical resources necessary for task accomplishment, since leaders may not exercise power to acquire these resources’ (Morris et al., 2005: 1335).

For those with fewer enactment behaviors, resource availability will be made vulnerable in high supervisor narcissism environments. Greenglass and Fiksenbaum (2009) argued that an inability to purposefully and actively manage socially-demanding environments hinders the accumulation of new resources and prevents mobilization when external threat reaches levels warranting use. As a result, employees run the inherent risk of resource depletion in situations laden with threat-generated ambiguity (Grant and Ashford, 2008) by not ‘producing a part of the environment they face’ (Pondy and Mitroff, 1979: 17).

Conversely creating an environment with built-in protective mechanisms is expected to neutralize resource vulnerability when supervisor narcissism is perceived as high. Schwarzer and Knoll (2003) maintained that proactivity translates into personal growth behavior, including the accrual of resources needed to offset interpersonal threat. Because enactment triggers heightened agentic control (e.g. influence, affect, attention; Hernes and Maitlis, 2010), exposure associated with narcissistic supervision will have only a minimal effect on resource availability. Based on this discussion, we offer the following hypothesis:

disp-quote.p: Hypothesis 3: Enactment behavior will moderate the relationship between narcissistic behavior and resource availability. Specifically, narcissistic supervision will be associated with decreased resource availability when enactment behavior is low. Conversely, high levels of enactment behavior will likely neutralize the effects of narcissistic supervision on resource availability (signifying no effect).

sec.title: Job performance
sec.p: In recent research, characteristics of supervisor behavior have been associated with favorable performance-related behaviors including ethical decision-making behavior (Piccolo et al., 2010), relationship building (Carmeli et al., 2009), and leader-member exchange quality (Cogliser et al., 2009). Importantly, malevolent leader behaviors demonstrate negative effects on subordinates at levels consistent in magnitude (Tepper et al., 2009). With respect to the current research, it is expected that narcissistic supervision will adversely affect subordinate performance (Campbell et al., 2011).

Hogan and Kaiser (2005) asserted that narcissistic leaders are capable of influencing contributions at individual, group and organizational levels if unrestricted. In support, recent research reports that group performance declined when managed by a narcissistic supervisor despite positive perceptions of leader attributes (Nevicka et al., 2011). At the dyadic level, narcissistic leaders consider others as inferior (Morf and Rhodewalt, 2001) leading to the suppression of job-relevant tools (instruction, mentoring, materials). Others note that leader egocentric behavior limits the cultivation of favorable exchange relationships, thus reducing subordinate accumulation of performance-enhancing feedback (Kets de Vries and Miller, 1985). Finally, Judge et al. (2006) confirmed that deteriorated social relationships led subordinates to pursue fewer opportunities to contribute in the form of citizenship behavior.

In contrast, research has identified enactment-related personality factors (e.g. conscientiousness and agreeableness; Bamberger and Bacharach, 2006) capable of neutralizing threat-performance relationships. Also documented is the importance of proactive coping as a mechanism for restoring control when supervisor behavior promotes vulnerability (Andiappan and Trevino, 2010). Specifically, McFarlin and Sweeney (2000) advocated the use of future-thinking tactics (e.g. coalition forming) when faced with a narcissistic supervisor to maintain positive contributions. Finally, scholars have documented the importance of focused enactment strategies, including network building and the accrual of social support, to shield subordinates from performance-depleting threat (Aspinwall and Taylor, 1997). Based on this discussion, we offer the following hypothesis:

disp-quote.p: Hypothesis 4: Enactment behavior will moderate the relationship between narcissistic behavior and job performance. Specifically, narcissistic supervision will be associated with decreased job performance when enactment behavior is low. Conversely, high levels of enactment behavior will likely neutralize the effects of narcissistic supervision on job performance (signifying no effect).

sec.title: Plan of the research
sec.p: To address concerns associated with single-study designs, scholars have encouraged the development of replication studies (Schmidt, 2009). McKinley (2010) argued that an ‘examination should not be considered complete after the first empirical test – repeated testing and replication should take place to converge on the explanation that has greater empirical validity’ (p. 63). Despite the fervor of this recommendation, in recent years validity-promoting replication studies remain largely scarce (Hochwarter et al., 2011).

To strengthen generalizability, three substantially different research populations were sampled using a literal replication format (Lykken, 1968). The first sample was expansive with respect to occupations and work contexts. Conversely, the second sample focused on one organization with employees possessing similar job duties and expectations. Finally, the third sample examined individuals at a comparable hierarchical level in multiple organizations. Identical measures were used across samples.

sec.title: Control variables
sec.p: We controlled for several demographic/work variables as well as personality in this research. Specifically, gender, years of company tenure, and number of hours worked per week were considered, owing to their shared variance with perceived narcissism and enactment behavior (Bean and Eisenberg, 2006). Further, the Big Five personality traits were controlled (Judge et al., 2006) based on findings confirming associations among their unique factors (extraversion, Wanberg and Kammeyer-Meuller, 2000; neuroticism, Olson-Buchanan and Boswell, 2008) as well as indices of perceived self-serving behavior (Witt et al., 2002) and interpretations of stressful workplace cues (Perrewé and Spector, 2002). Finally, studies substantiate relationships between these personality dimensions and the outcomes examined in this research (Dudley et al., 2006). As an example, Harrington (2007) described particular situations where conscientiousness would trigger heightened frustration.

sec.title: Sample 1
sec.p: Consistent with previous studies (Munyon et al., 2010), students in a large business course were given a survey to be completed by a full-time employee (>35 hours). We provided 487 surveys to students for distribution and responses were requested within one month. At the end of the data collection cycle, we received 461 completed surveys used in subsequent analyses. Students received course credits for participation. The sample consisted of 221 women (48%), averaged 10 years of company tenure (range 1–38 years), and 43 hours of work per week (range 35–71). Both white- and blue-collar positions were included, however, professional employees comprised the majority of the sample (>80%).

sec.title: Sample 2
sec.p: Human resource managers of a medium-size building/real estate company forwarded surveys to all of its 179 full-time workers through intra-office mail. A note was sent to employees one week prior to distribution outlining study procedures. Included in the packet was a stamped, return envelope addressed directly to the researchers. Email reminders were sent one week and two weeks after initial survey distribution. After three weeks, we received a total of 137 surveys. One survey was returned blank, and was thus withdrawn, leading to a final sample size of 136 (response rate = 76%). The sample consisted of 78 women (57%), averaged nine years of company tenure (range 1–21 years), and 47 hours of work per week (range 40–62). Current staffing statistics indicated that the population was 56.3 percent female at the approximate time of the data collection (other demographic data were unavailable).

sec.title: Sample 3
sec.p: We distributed a survey to all 148 members of a professional organization who were attending their association’s national conference (one of the study’s authors was a presenter – no research content was discussed during any session). Most participants were mid- to upper-level managers whose work activities focused on increasing product quality. Two drop boxes were used on site, and sufficient time between sessions was available for completion. Each packet contained a stamped return envelope if this approach was preferred. We received a total of 111 returned surveys (105 in the drop box; six in the mail) for an overall response rate of 75 percent. The sample consisted of 65 women (59%), averaged eight years of company tenure (range 2–32 years), and 46 hours of work per week (range 42–75).

sec.title: Personality
sec.p: The Big Five personality dimensions were measured using a scale developed by Gosling et al. (2003). Specifically, two items (one of which had a reverse construct meaning) measured neuroticism (anxious/easily upset and calm/emotionally stable, r = .55 – Sample 1; r = .58 – Sample 2; r = .48 – Sample 3 ), extraversion (extraverted/enthusiastic and reserved/quiet, r = .62 – Sample 1; r = .50 – Sample 2; r = .54 – Sample 3), agreeableness (critical/quarrelsome and sympathetic/warm, r = .51 – Sample 1; r = .61 – Sample 2; r = .60 – Sample 3), conscientiousness (dependable/self-disciplined and disorganized/careless, r = .60 – Sample 1; r = .57 – Sample 2; r = .49 – Sample 3), and openness (open to new experiences/complex and conventional/uncreative, r = .62 – Sample 1; r = .63 – Sample 2; r = .51 – Sample 3). A five-point response format ranging from strongly disagree (1) to strongly agree (5) was used.

sec.title: Perceived supervisor narcissism
sec.p: Based on conceptualizations found in both personality and leadership research domains (American Psychiatric Association DSM-IV, 2000; Campbell and Campbell, 2009; Twenge et al., 2008), we developed a six-item scale to measure perceived supervisor narcissism (α = .93 – Sample 1; α = .88 – Sample 2; α = .85 – Sample 3). The six items included: ‘My boss is a very self-centered person,’ ‘My boss has an inflated view of him/herself,’ My boss brags about him/herself to get positive strokes from others,’ ‘My boss will do one favor as long as he/she gets two or more in return,’ ‘My boss will go out of his/her way to cause me harm to get ahead’ and ‘My boss always has to be the center of attention no matter what.’ A five-point response format ranging from strongly disagree (1) to strongly agree (5) was used. Factor analyses (principle axis) of scale items produced a one-factor solution in each sample, explaining 81.3 percent (Sample 1), 77.7 percent (Sample 2), and 80.2 percent (Sample 3) of the underlying item variance. Across samples, all items correlated at a level greater than .70. No cross loadings with other scale items emerged.

sec.title: Perceived enactment behavior
sec.p: Because of our inability to identify an adequate measure of environment enactment, we developed a five-item scale. Consistent with prior theorizations (Drazin et al., 2008; Weick, 1995), items included: ‘I have worked to make things go the way I want them to go while on the job,’ ‘I have created “my world” at work where I can do things the way I want,’ ‘I have worked to make things at work as predictable as possible for me,’ ‘I have created my own reality at work in that I have things set up the way I want,’ and ‘People mostly leave me alone at work and let me do what I need to do to be successful’ (α = .84 – Sample 1; α = .88 – Sample 2; α = .87 – Sample 3). A five-point response format ranging from strongly disagree (1) to strongly agree (5) was used. Factor analyses produced a one-factor solution in each sample, which explained 77.4 percent (Sample 1), 79.1 percent (Sample 2), and 81.3 percent (Sample 3) of the underlying item variance. Across samples, all enactment items correlated at a level greater than .72. No cross loadings with other scale items emerged.

sec.title: Work frustration
sec.p: Self-report work frustration was measured using a three-item scale developed by Peters et al. (1980). ‘Being frustrated comes with the job’ represents a scale item (α = .87 – Sample 1; α = .84 – Sample 2; α = .80 – Sample 3). A five-point response format ranging from strongly disagree (1) to strongly agree (5) was used.

sec.title: Job tension
sec.p: We measured self-report job tension (α = .89 – Sample 1; α = .84 – Sample 2; α = .82 – Sample 3) with House and Rizzo’s (1972) six-item index. ‘My job tends to directly affect my health’ represents a scale item. A five-point response format ranging from strongly disagree (1) to strongly agree (5) was used.

sec.title: Resource availability
sec.p: Accessibility to work resources (α = .90 – Sample 1; α = .89 – Sample 2; α = .85 – Sample 3) was measured using a six-item self-report scale developed by Hochwarter et al. (2008). ‘When I feel like my battery is run down at work, I can get others to pick up some of the load’ represents a scale item. A five-point response format ranging from strongly disagree (1) to strongly agree (5) was used.

sec.title: Self-report job performance
sec.p: Self-report job performance (α = .84 – Sample 1; α = .90 – Sample 2; α = .83 – Sample 3) was measured with a 10-item scale developed by Wright et al. (1995). A representative item is: ‘I am willing to go beyond what the situation requires and to act before being asked by my supervisor.’ A five-point response format ranging from strongly disagree (1) to strongly agree (5) was used.

sec.title: Data analysis
sec.p: We conducted hierarchical moderated regression analyses (Cohen et al., 2003) to examine each interactive relationship. Control variables (i.e. gender, employer tenure, work hours, and Big Five personality dimensions) were entered in Step 1 while main effect and non-linear main effect terms were included in Steps 2 and 3. Cortina (1993) noted that bivariate interactions in hierarchical regression may be significant largely owing to their overlap with unmeasured nonlinear terms. More recently, Edwards (2008) encouraged scholars to consider nonlinear terms as a general rule when conducting moderated regression analyses. The final step consisted of the supervisor narcissism–enactment behavior interactive term (Cohen et al., 2003). All variables were mean centered prior to their use.

Finally, collinearity diagnostics were conducted to assess the influence of method variance given the method of data collection. Specifically, we calculated variance inflation factor (VIF) scores, which measure the extent to which collinearity among the predictors affects precision of a regression model. VIF scores greater than 10 are typically considered problematic (Hair et al., 1998). As an additional check, we conducted tolerance tests, which provide a complimentary index. Scores below .10 provide evidence of collinearity (Tabachnick and Fidell, 2001).

sec.title: Sample 1
sec.p: Tables 1 and 2 report descriptive statistics and regression results for all samples. Correlations among substantive predictors and outcomes are modest by conventional standards. For example, only one bivariate relationship (i.e. tension-frustration in Sample 1) exceeded .40 (.46, Sample 2). Finally, the relationship between self-report performance and narcissistic supervision was consistent with previous abusive leader studies using multi-source indices (Harris et al., 2007).

sec.p: Regression analyses indicated that supervisor narcissism–enactment behavior interaction term predicted frustration in the final step (β = -.16, p < .01, ΔAdjR2 = .02, p < .01). Moreover, this term predicted job tension (β = -.25, p < .01, ΔAdjR2 = .03, p < .01), resource availability (β = .09, p < .01, ΔAdjR2 = .02, p < .01) and job performance (β = .10, p < .01, ΔAdjR2 = .02, p < .01) in subsequent final steps. With the highest VIF score being less than 2.0 and the lowest tolerance score in excess of .50, evidence for multicollinearity is minimal.

sec.title: Post hoc tests
sec.p: To examine the form of the significant interactive effects, simple slope tests were conducted (Aiken and West, 1991). Figures 1–4 illustrate the significant supervisor narcissism–enactment behavior effects on work frustration, job tension, resource availability, and performance. For low enactment employees, supervisor narcissism unfavorably predicted work frustration (β = .25, p < .01), job tension (β = .31, p < .01), resource availability (β = -.19, p < .05), and performance (β = -.20, p < .05). Conversely, supervisor narcissism had little effect on each work outcome for high enactment behavior employees.

sec.title: Sample 2
sec.p: The supervisor narcissism–enactment behavior interaction term failed to predict frustration (β = -.03, ns). Conversely, the term predicted job tension (b = -.28, p < .01, ΔAdjR2 = .02, p < .01), resource availability (b = .15, p < .01, ΔAdjR2 = .05, p < .01), and job performance (b = .14, p < .01, ΔAdjR2 = .03, p < .01) in subsequent final steps. With the highest VIF score being less than 1.8 and the lowest tolerance score in excess of .55, evidence for multicollinearity is minimal.

sec.title: Post hoc tests
sec.p: Results of slope tests, shown in Figures 5–7, illustrate the significant interactive effects. For low enactment behavior employees, narcissistic supervision unfavorably predicted job tension (β = .33, p < .01), resource availability (β = -.22, p < .05), and performance (β = -.17, p < .05). For individuals with high levels of enactment behavior, narcissistic supervision had little effect on any outcome.

sec.title: Sample 3
sec.p: The supervisor narcissism–enactment behavior interaction term predicted job frustration (b = -.20, p < .05, ΔAdjR2 = .03, p < .05), resource availability (b = .10, p < .01, ΔAdjR2 = .04, p < .01), and job performance (b = .18, p < .05, ΔAdjR2 = .02, p < .05). Conversely, the term failed to predict job tension (β = -.18, p =.08, ns). With the highest VIF score being less than 2.1 and the lowest tolerance score in excess of .48, evidence for multicollinearity is minimal.

sec.p: Results of slope tests illustrate the significant interactive effects. For low enactment behavior employees, narcissistic supervision unfavorably predicted work frustration (β = .27, p < .05), resource availability (β = -.26, p < .05), and performance (β = -.22, p < .05). For individuals with high levels of enactment behavior, narcissistic supervision had little effect on any outcome.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: To extend prior research, we developed a multi-sample investigation to examine narcissistic supervisor–environment enacting relationships on outcomes considered important to scholars and managers (frustration, job tension, resource availability, and performance). Across studies, results largely confirmed the threat neutralizing potential of enactment for individuals reporting heightened levels of supervisor narcissism. Similarly, results established that an inability to proactively create and manage one’s work context prompted unfavorable outcomes in heightened supervisor narcissism settings. Implications of these results for scholarship and practice are discussed.

sec.title: Scholarly implications
sec.p: Contributions to multiple scholarly domains warrant brief explanation. For example, results reported here contribute to the burgeoning body of research examining abusive workplace relationships (Biron, 2010; Tepper et al., 2011). However, our concentration on narcissistic leader behavior extends existing research (Tepper et al., 2011) by providing a more refined view of tenuous dyadic relationships plaguing many organizations (Mitchell and Ambrose, 2007). To date, studies dedicated to understanding narcissistic leader behavior on subordinates’ health, attitudes, and behaviors are strikingly absent in contemporary research.

As conceptualized, an additional contribution was the consideration of individual environment enactment, which represents a previously unmeasured moderator of narcissistic leader–worker outcome relationships. In developing this research, we assumed that supervisor narcissism possessed crisis-like manifestations (hostility, aggression, and insulting behavior; Penney and Spector, 2002), including the ability to trigger subordinate uncertainty (Weick, 1995). In support of enactment’s threat-attenuating role, Weick (2003) contended that arousal associated with external vulnerability may spur restorative activity for some, but not all, individuals. Because low enactment employees are unable to dedicate adequate coping assets to the renewal process (i.e. the warning is disregarded, tools for restoration are lacking/absent), exposure will demand constant attention. Subordinates are likely to suffer a myriad of maladaptive outcomes as a result of the constant assault on finite resources (Ferris et al., 2009).

For those committed to proactive enactment, the threat associated with narcissistic supervision ‘serves as a warning that there is a stimulus to which attention must be paid and that one’s well-being may be at stake’ (Maitlis and Sonenshein, 2010: 566). Weick (2003) argued that enactment influences coping in contentious environments by augmenting perceptions of control and clarifying relationships between effort and stress reduction. Others contend that behavior that is both self-protecting and proactive is most valuable in highly demanding environments (Carver and Connor-Smith, 2010). Our results are supportive of these arguments, pending verification studies.

sec.title: Practical implications
sec.p: Managerial implications associated with our results warrant brief discussion. First, the pervasiveness of narcissistic supervision needs to be acknowledged, appearing to be ‘alive and well’ in many work settings. Second, decision-makers must be responsive to its influence, as supervision perceived as egocentric was negatively associated with each study outcome. Research suggests that a healthy level of narcissism is productive given the associated confidence, extraversion, and social competence (Fox and Freeman, 2011). However, when supervisors become too preoccupied with the pursuit of self-interested outcomes, social relations decline, strain increases, and productivity deteriorates (Miller and Campbell, 2008). Instead of allowing work relations to spiral downward, managers should closely monitor and adjust dyadic relations to ensure that supervisors do what is best for their subordinates, team and organization rather than solely for themselves.

sec.title: Strengths and limitations
sec.p: A notable strength of this research was the inclusion of three unique samples that provided consistent results in both magnitude and direction. Replications allow for more definitive statements to be made regarding hypothesized relationships when confirming results are produced (Hochwarter et al., 2011). Moreover, controlling for the Big Five personality dimensions was beneficial in that doing so allowed outcome variation to emerge that was not accounted for by extant individual differences. Finally, a more conservative test of study hypotheses was provided by considering a myriad of the theoretically- relevant control variables (Judge et al., 2006).

Limitations include our reliance on self-report data across studies. As a potential remedy, we conducted additional tests to document the impact of multicollinearity. Results provided minimal evidence of concern. Likewise, scholars (Podsakoff et al., 2003) argue that significant cross-product terms are largely unaffected by method issues, owing to the analysis format embedded in moderated regression procedures. Finally, recent research reports uniformity between self and other’s perceptions of narcissism, confirming the use of similar descriptors (i.e. arrogant) across sources (Carlson et al., 2011). Nonetheless, having both supervisor reports of their own narcissistic tendencies as well as those of the target would have been preferred, as doing so would explicate factors capable of biasing perceptions of malevolent leader behavior.

In addition, the use of supervisor narcissism and enactment scales developed specifically for this research may be considered a limitation despite the rationale used to create survey items. We acknowledge that both constructs are likely multi-dimensional, represented by both individual difference and contextual factors (Fox and Freeman, 2011; Given-Wilson et al., 2011). Data collection constraints imposed by the participating data sources required the development of indices that were unidimensional and possessed face validity. Adequate internal reliability estimates and factor structures (factor analysis tests confirmed a psychometrically adequate measure possessing the predicted unidimensional structure) notwithstanding, scholars may find value in utilizing rigorously validated scales in situations warranting such an approach.

sec.title: Directions for future research
sec.p: Since both the narcissistic supervisor and enactment constructs are in their early stages of development, much work is needed to establish their principal theoretical properties as well as predictive efficacy. Hindering research to date has been the shared acceptance that narcissism is ‘highly complex, difficult to define and measure, and linked to a number of somewhat conflicting theoretical perspectives’ (Morf and Rhodewalt, 2001: 177). Moreover, scholars’ overreliance on student samples in contrived settings (Twenge and Campbell, 2003) has delayed the expansion of narcissism research in organizational settings. As a potential first step, research should focus on ‘good’ versus ‘bad’ forms of supervisor narcissism (Campbell, 2001), considering contextual factors that hold promise for explaining important leader and subordinate outcomes.

Similarly, leader intentionality needs to be further explored. In this research, it was theorized that leader behavior was driven largely by innate self-serving needs (Pincus and Lukowitsky, 2010). However, less self-serving explanations for perceived aberrant behavior exist. Adopting a moral exclusion perspective, Tepper et al. (2011) examined the predictive utility of supervisor perceptions of deep-level similarity, relationship conflict, and subordinate performance. Also, Fox and Freeman’s (2011) discussion of leader narcissism, counterproductive behaviors, and citizenship integrated cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) as an explanatory mechanism. Understanding supervisor motives for self-serving behavior will likely require a more expansive view of person, situation, and temporal issues than what currently exists.

Similarly, science and practice may be augmented with a heightened appreciation of positive narcissistic behavior. For example, research has yet to identify potential benefits of working for a narcissistic leader, especially as they relate to the accrual of desired resources relative to employees without aggressive supervisor support. Freeman and Duff (2006) identified eight narcissism types, many of which are likely associated with favorable subordinate outcomes (e.g. healthy, helpful, group).

Furthermore, developing a richer understanding of environment enactment is needed (Dierdorff and Morgeson, 2007). For example, an appreciation of the initiation (i.e. why is it undertaken), development (i.e. tactics used), and outcomes (i.e. coping, resource accumulation, performance/career satisfaction) of enactment will likely expose new and interesting research questions (Aspinwall, 2011), as will a consideration of actor and target mood expressions throughout the process. Recently, Lindebaum and Fielden (2010) argued that the enactment of negative emotions (i.e. anger) could facilitate desired outcomes in settings that relied on negotiations to achieve success. Because of its associated emotionality, understanding the influence of individual different factors on enactment’s predictors and consequences has considerable merit.

Finally, research examining the potentially detrimental effects of excessive enactment is considered necessary. Because enactment tends to be more individual than collective, it is presumably susceptible to egocentric manifestations if not calibrated (Weick et al., 2005). For example, the summative control associated with positive enactment activity (Maitlis and Sonenhein, 2010) may cause some individuals to hoard resources or develop other inappropriate strategies to maintain or enhance what has been amassed. In terms of potential remedies for narcissistic behavior (i.e. subordinate or leader), a balanced approach requires the identification of cultural or policy changes shown to positively influence social relations and resource fairness, as well.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Narcissistic behavior and proactive threat-reducing activity have become important components of all firms’ social fabric, and are expected to increase in years to come. As such, developing a richer understanding of individual coping practices associated with this form of interpersonal treatment is a concern to both scholars and practicing managers. We hope this research will encourage others to evaluate and extend our arguments and findings. By doing so, we are optimistic that employee productivity and quality of work life will be enhanced.
